questions.text: Identify the marked blood vessel in this MR Angiogram-
questions.solution:
Correct Choice:

  1. Superficial temporal artery:- It a terminal branch of the external carotid artery. Runs upwards from the site of origin.

Introduction to MR angiography:-

MR angiography is a modality to visualised intracranial as well as extra-cranial blood vessels without the risk of radiation. It can be done with or without contrast.

Arterial anatomy of MR Angiography:

  1. Circle of Wilis ( axial orientation)
  2. Neck angiography (coronal orientation):

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice B. Basilar artery: part of a posterior circulation.

Choice C. Middle meningeal artery:- branch of ICA.

Choice D. Occipital artery:- part of posterior circulation.

Reference: https://images.app.goo.gl/Vvm9vKRKghVCxq66A

Image references :-

https://mrimaster.com/anatomy-brain-cerebral-arteries/

https://mrimaster.com/anatomy-neck-arteries/

NCCT:- Non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice for detection of the renal calculus. Noncontrast CT has the highest sensitivity among all imaging modalities for renal calculus. It can also exclude other causes of flank pain like diverticulitis, cholecystitis, pancreatitis, appendicitis, ovarian torsion, pyelonephritis, bladder outlet obstruction, etc. Hence, it is the modality of choice in urolithiasis.

All stones are visualized in CT, except indinavir stones.

The Hounsfield unit (HU) value of the calculus gives a rough idea about the composition of the stone, uric acid calculi are usually 200–400 HU, while calcium oxalate calculi are 600-1200 HU More importantly, a greater attenuation predicts lesser responsiveness to lithotripsy. Also, a heterogeneous appearance of the stone, with interposed areas of low and high attenuation predicts increased fragility and hence a greater susceptibility for Shockwave lithotripsy (SWL).

Incorrect Choices explanation :-

Choice A - USG is the 1st investigation in the patient suspected with the renal colic. However, there is high chances of false negatives (missing a calculus). Reasons of high false negativity includes :-

  1. Bowel gas obscure the mid and lower ureters
  2. Ureter are not visicle on the USG unless they are dilated i.e. hydroureter
  3. USG is subjective to the operator.

Choice C - CECT :- Usually Contrast Enhanced CT scan is not preferred to visualize the calculi, as calculi can easily be missed due to radio-opaque contrast media filling the pelvicalyceal system.

Choice D - Ureteroscopy :- Invasive investigation, usually have higher sensitivity in visualisation of the lower ureteric and bladder calculi.

Key takeaway:-

  • USG is the 1st investigation in the patient suspected with the renal colic. However, there is high chances of false negatives (missing a calculus).
  • Non-contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice for detection of the renal calculus.
  • All stones are visualized in CT, except indinavir stones.

questions.text: A 60 yr old patient came with inability to bear weight following a trivial trauma and the following finding on the PBH and thigh x rays. She has a history of weight loss. Whatis the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Image Description:

There is well defined lytic lesion is noyed involving the neck of the femur with associated pathological fracture.

Explanation:-

Skeletal metastases are defined as tumors involving bone, which originate from another distal site.

Metastases are the most common malignant tumors of the skeletal system. Approximately 70% of all malignant tumors are metastatic in origin, with only 30% being primary in nature.

The most common primary sites are in the breast, lung, prostate, kidney, thyroid, and bowel. With the exception of tumors of the central nervous system and basal cell carcinoma of the skin, almost every malignant tumor can metastasize to bone.

Bone involvement in metastases occurs by means of three main mechanisms:

(1) direct extension,

(2) retrograde venous flow

(3) seeding with tumor emboli via the blood circulation which is the most common route of spread.

Age

Most patients are older than 40 years. In children <5 years, skeletal metastases usually occur from neuroblastoma. Metastases between the age group of 10 and 25 years commonly occur from Ewing sarcoma and osteosarcoma, and between 20 and 35 years, they occur from Hodgkin lymphoma.

Sex

In females, the carcinoma of the breast is responsible for majority of all bone metastases followed by the carcinomas of thyroid, kidney, and uterus. In males, carcinoma prostate is the most common primary focus, followed by the carcinoma of the lung.

Site

They are most often found in the axial skeleton and other sites of residual red marrow. Thus, the common sites for metastases are vertebrae, pelvis, proximal femora and humeri, skull, sternum, and ribs. Metastases to bones of hand and feet are rare and almost 50% of these are due to the carcinoma of the lung.

Clinical Picture

The lesions may be entirely asymptomatic or present with vague bone pains. Occasionally, a pathological fracture through the metastatic lesion may bring it to notice. Weight loss, cachexia, anemia, and even fever may be seen in the later stages.

Imaging Features

Plain Radiographs

Bone metastases may be lytic, sclerotic, or mixed lytic and sclerotic. As a metastatic lesion grows in the medullary cavity, the surrounding bone is remodeled by means of either osteoclastic or osteoblastic processes.

The majority (75%) of metastases is osteolytic. Some metastases (15%) are predominantly osteoblastic, e.g., from prostate, stomach, and carcinoid. Mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic metastasis (10%) occur from carcinoma of the breast and occasionally, lung.

In females, the carcinoma of the breast is responsible for majority of all bone metastases followed by the carcinomas of thyroid, kidney, and uterus. In males, carcinoma prostate is the most common primary focus, followed by the carcinoma of the lung.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A:- Eosinophilic granuloma :- Well defined lytic lesion with beveled age, usually seen in the child age group, can involve axial flat bones as well as long bones.

Choice B :- Osteoarticular tuberculosis can occur in the spine, hip, knee, foot, elbow, wrist, hand, shoulder and as diaphyseal foci. It has not been reported to affect the mandible or the temporomandibular joint. The major method of spread is hematogenous. The most common method of spread to the vertebral body is through the Batson's venous plexus.

Choice C :- Brown tumors are usually multiple in number, associated with other features of hyperparathyroidism like bone resorption (sub-periosteal , intracortical,etc.)

Key takeaway:-

  • Metastases are the most common malignant tumors of the skeletal system. Approximately 70% of all malignant tumors are metastatic in origin, with only 30% being primary in nature.
  • The majority (75%) of metastases is osteolytic. Some metastases (15%) are predominantly osteoblastic, e.g., from prostate, stomach, and carcinoid. Mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic metastasis (10%) occur from carcinoma of the breast and occasionally, lung.
  • In females, the carcinoma of the breast is responsible for majority of all bone metastases followed by the carcinomas of thyroid, kidney, and uterus.
  • In males, carcinoma prostate is the most common primary focus, followed by the carcinoma of the lung.

Reference: https://images.app.goo.gl/wm25DTLvn3qibqPLA

choices.text: Patchy infiltrates are seen in pyogenic pneumonia
Interstitial infiltrates are seen in mycoplasma pneumonia
Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates are seen in malignancy
Aspiration pneumonia is more common in posterior segment of upper lobes and superior segment of lower lobes

questions.text: A 47 year old diabetic patient came with fever, malaise and productive cough. Which of the following is an incorrect statement?
questions.solution:
Pyogenic pneumonia refers toa type of bacterial pneumonia, characterized by the production of pus in the lungs, commonly caused by bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae

Pneumococcal pneumonia is caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. It is the commonest communityacquired pneumonia and can occur at any age. The clinical presentation is in form of abrupt onset offever, chills, cough and chest pain, often associated with bloody or rusty sputum. The organism tends to affect the terminal airways first and then disseminates to the surrounding segments giving rise to the classical unilateral airspace pneumonia An air bronchogram is commonly present andthis is a characteristic feature. The volume of the lobe usually remains unchanged. Classically,it causes a lobar pattern of consolidation but may sometimes even have a bronchopneumonic orinterstitial pattern. Occasionally, early during the disease, a spherical or round pneumonia may beseen, particularly in children. One study that investigated the radiographic appearance in 81 inpatients with culture documented pneumococcal pneumonia, demonstrated a lobar pattern of consolidation in 81% of patients. Lobar consolidation was focal in 48% and multifocal in 33%. A bronchopneumonic pattern was seen in 19% cases.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B :- Interstitial infiltrates are seen in mycoplasma pneumonia

Interstitial Pneumonia, the infection results in diffuse edema of the airway walls along withinflammatory cellular infiltration which extends from the peri-bronchial tissues into the interlobularsepta. The usual causes of acute interstitial pneumonia are viral or Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection.

The chest radiographs show generalized hyperaeration, widespread peribronchial thickening,increased reticular markings or small ill-defined nodules.

Choice C:- Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrates are seen in malignancy

Hilar lymphadenopathy with lung infiltrate is commonly seen with adenocarcinoma of the lung. Adenocarcinoma usually presented with unresolving consolidation and lymphadenopathy. It can also be seen with the tuberculosis infection.

Choice D:- Aspiration pneumonia is more common in posterior segment of upper lobes and superior segment of lower lobes.

Aspiration pneumonia: Occurs in patients with impaired consciousness, chronic debilitatingdiseases, structural abnormalities of the pharynx and esophagus, neuromuscular disorders,impaired swallowing mechanisms, indwelling tracheal or esophageal/gastric tubes and inpostoperative patients, due to inhalation of bacteria, food, gastric contents, etc. leading toparenchymal inflammation or edema. It has several different pathophysiologicalaspects-bacterial pneumonia caused by the oral flora, chemical pneumonitis by gastric acid orexogenous lipids such as paraffin liquid and granulomatous reaction to foreign bodies. It occurs inthe gravity dependent portions of the lung, so in recumbent patient it involves the posteriorsegment of the upper lobes and the superior segment of the lower lobes whereas in an erectpatient, aspiration is more likely to involve bilateral basal segments, middle lobe, and lingular lobe.

On imaging, it is often seen as a bronchopneumonia or bronchiolitis pattern.

Aspirated material may sometimes be seen in the bronchial lumen. A lung abscess may also beseen in bacterial aspiration.

Key Takeaway:

Lobar consolidation (not patchy infiltrates) is the hallmark of pyogenic pneumonia (e.g., pneumococcal pneumonia).

Reference: https://images.app.goo.gl/RkJsRM9ngribXLx29
